scenes.title: Three-front war for growth
scenes.main_point: AI raised expectations, collapsed channels, and intensified competition for every value prop.
scenes.scene_summary: AI raised expectations, collapsed distribution, and put incumbents, startups, and customers in competition.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Delicate watercolor painting style, soft washes, visible brush strokes, muted tones.
In a modern office, a product leader stands before a whiteboard labeled “Expectations,” “Channels,” and “Competition,” with simple AI icons and downward arrows.
Around them, faint silhouettes of an incumbent, a startup founder, and a customer face inward, creating a tense three-front standoff.

scenes.title: A new playbook: Trust
scenes.main_point: Growth increasingly depended on trust as the core organizing principle.
scenes.scene_summary: A new growth playbook emerged, and it centered on one concept: trust.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Delicate watercolor painting style, soft washes, visible brush strokes, muted tones.
In the same war-room from scene 1, the same small team of strategists stands around the table, their tense posture easing.
They replace the three-front battle map with a single simple diagram labeled “Trust,” quietly aligning around it with focused resolve.

scenes.title: Classic channels stopped working
scenes.main_point: SEO, SEM, and corporate social degraded as AI and platform incentives intercepted traffic and raised costs.
scenes.scene_summary: SEO, paid search, and corporate social got pricier and weaker as AI intercepted attention.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Delicate watercolor painting style, soft washes, visible brush strokes, muted tones.
Same startup founder at a desk with a laptop showing a fading “SEO” graph and rising “SEM CPC” numbers, while a large AI chat bubble answers above the search bar, blocking clicks.
Around them, corporate social posts have link icons crossed out, conveying frustration in a simple office setting.

scenes.title: Trust-based acquisition channels
scenes.main_point: Employee-led social, creators, community, and product-led brand built word of mouth and durable trust.
scenes.scene_summary: Employee voices, creators, community, and product experience drove word of mouth and trust.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Delicate watercolor painting style, soft washes, visible brush strokes, muted tones.
Same startup team from prior scenes gathered around a table, sharing phones and laptops as employee posts, creator shout-outs, and community messages ripple outward in simple icon-like waves.
In the same minimalist office setting, a product box sits open at center, suggesting word-of-mouth trust spreading with calm confidence.

scenes.title: Trust-based retention beats commoditization
scenes.main_point: As AI commoditized efficiency and cost advantages, retention depended on confidence in ongoing outcomes.
scenes.scene_summary: As AI commoditized features, users stayed with products they trusted to deliver outcomes.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Delicate watercolor painting style, soft washes, visible brush strokes, muted tones.
In the same minimalist office from prior scenes, the founder and a small team watch two product panels: one labeled “cheap/efficient” fading into identical copies, the other labeled “trusted outcomes” holding steady.
They place a protective hand over the “trusted outcomes” panel as the commoditized panels blur together, conveying calm confidence.

scenes.title: Operational shift and closing warning
scenes.main_point: Trust required aligned teams, high shipping velocity, and building in public before collapse accelerated.
scenes.scene_summary: Teams aligned, shipped fast, built in public, and shifted before channels collapsed faster.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Delicate watercolor painting style, soft washes, visible brush strokes, muted tones.
The same startup team from earlier scenes stands together at a shared desk, engineers, product, and support aligned, placing small “micro-release” notes onto a public roadmap board.
Behind them, a faded wall of old acquisition-channel posters peels away, while a simple upward “trust” line on a whiteboard suggests compounding and a quiet closing warning.
